Review Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica as base catalyst and adsorbent Toshiyuki Yokoi a Yoshihiro Kubota b ⁎ Takashi Tatsumi a 1 a Chemical Resources Laboratory, Tokyo Institute of Technology 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8503,Japan b Division of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering,Yokohama National University, 79-5 Tokiwadai, Hodogaya-ku, Yokohama 240-8501, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 45 339 3926; fax: +81 45 339 3941. 1 Tel: +81 45 924 5238; fax: +81 45 924 5282. Graphical abstract . Highlights ► Amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas were synthesized by post-synthesis grafting and direct co-condensation methods. ► Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica prepared was also prepared via anionic surfactant templated route. ► Various applications of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica are described. Mesoporous molecular sieves with size-tunable mesopores have been well developed and have attracted a great deal of attention because of their controllable structures and compositions, which make them suitable for a wide range of applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, chromatography, etc. The pore size of mesoporous silica is large enough to accommodate a variety of large molecules, and the high density of silanol groups on the pore wall is beneficial to the introduction of functional groups with a high coverage. Actually, various kinds of surface modifications have been conducted for providing new functions for the surfaces. Among various functional groups, the introduction of the amino groups onto the mesopores has enabled us to use amino-functionalized mesoporous materials as solid-base catalysts and adsorbents. Meanwhile, “anionic surfactant templated mesoporous silica (AMS)” has been synthesized via a novel templating route for preparing mesoporous silicas based on the self-assembly of anionic surfactants and inorganic precursors in the presence of aminosilane or quaternized aminosilane as a co-structure-directing agent. AMSs are synthetically interesting not only for their structural diversity, including chiral properties, but also for the chance of functionalizing the pore surface by removing the surfactant by solvent extraction, resulting in the formation of the mesoporous silica with aminopropyl groups intact. Thus obtained amino-functionalized AMS can be applied to solid-base catalysis, adsorption, drug delivery, etc. This review gives an overview on the recent development of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica. In particular, the difference in the state and catalytic activity of amino groups between the functionalized mesoporous silicas synthesized via anionic and cationic surfactants templating routes is featured. Interesting applications of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica besides solid-base catalyst are also described. Keywords Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica Adsorbent Solid-base catalyst 1 Introduction Since the discovery by Mobil researchers [1,2] and Kuroda and his co-workers [3,4], mesoporous silica molecular sieves with large pore diameters ranging from 2 to 50nm have been well developed and have attracted a great deal of attention because of their high specific surface areas, size-tunable mesopores and compositions. In general, the formation of well-ordered mesostructured silica has been promoted by a micelle-templating method including electrostatic charge-matching and electrically neutral pathways using surfactants as a structure-directing agent (SDA) [5,6]. Mesoporous silica is obtained after removing the surfactant by calcination and/or extraction methods from the mesostructured silica-micelle composite. Note that the pore wall of mesoporous silica consists of amorphous silica network; on the other hand, microporous silica molecular sieves, zeolites, have a rigid crystalline structure with a network of interconnected micropores. Consequently, chemical, hydrothermal and mechanical stabilities of mesoporous silica are inferior to zeolites with pore sizes restricted to around 1.5nm. Nevertheless, the pore size of mesoporous silica is large enough to accommodate a variety of large molecules, and the high density of silanol groups on the pore wall is beneficial to the introduction of functional groups with a high coverage [7]. Actually, several kinds of surface modifications have been conducted for providing new functions for the surfaces [8–11], making them suitable for a wide range of applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, chromatography, etc., for bulky molecules that cannot enter micropores of zeolites [12–15]. 2 Preparation of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica In general, the functionalization of the surface of the mesopores has been achieved by direct co-condensation and post-synthesis grafting methods using organoalkoxysilane, (R2O)4− n -Si-R1 n (n =1–3) (Fig. 1) [16–19]. A direct co-condensation method (i.e., “one-pot synthesis”) is based on the co-condensation of a tetraalkoxysilane and organoalkoxysilanes in the aqueous solution containing surfactant to produce inorganic–organic hybrid networks through sol–gel chemistry. On the other hand, a post-synthesis grafting method is based on the silylation of organoalkoxysilane with surface silanol groups on the mesopores of the pre-fabricated mesoporous silica. Organic–inorganic hybrid mesoporous materials have also been prepared by using the alkoxysilane monomer bridged by an organic group, e.g., 1,2-bis(trimethoxysilyl)ethane and 1,4-bis(triethoxysilyl)-benzene, as silica source [19–25]. Although this method leads to a homogeneous distribution of organic fragments within the framework, the variation of functional groups introduced as well as mesostructure of the materials is limited. 2.1 Difference between post-synthesis grafting and direct co-condensation synthesis methods A high loading of functional groups in mesoporous silicas would enhance the performance of the materials [26–30]. However, such functionalized silicas exhibit poorer structural ordering than non-functionalized mesoporous silica materials, as evidenced by less-distinct X-ray diffraction patterns. Meanwhile, uneven distribution of functional groups in the mesopores adversely affects the performance of the material because the high density of functional groups on the surface may prevent the diffusion of molecules in the mesopore. Therefore, the balance of the high loading of functional groups, the uniform distribution and the open-pore space should be attained as a whole to obtain materials that give a high performance. Lim and his co-workers compared the structure, stability, and reactivities of vinyl-functionalized MCM-41 samples prepared by post-synthesis grafting and direct co-condensation synthesis processes [31]. They concluded that vinyl groups appeared to be distributed non-uniformly in vinyl-functionalized MCM-41 prepared by the post-synthesis grafting, and that, on the other hand, the direct synthesis method resulted in uniformly distributed vinyl groups within mesopore channels. For amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas, although Brunel and his co-workers reported on the difference in the reactivity of aminopropyl groups between the neutral amine surfactant-templated mesoporous silicas prepared via grafting and co-condensation routes [32,33], the difference in the location of amino groups has been scarcely reported. Therefore, we have conducted comparative studies on the amino-functionalized MCM-41 materials prepared via direct co-condensation and post-synthesis grafting methods using organoalkoxysilanes containing different numbers of amino groups and the summary is described below [34]. 2.1.1 Preparations of amino-functionalized MCM-41 Three organoalkoxysilanes, 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (N silane), 6-amino-4-azahexyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2NHCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (NN silane) and 9-amino-4,7-diazanonyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2NHCH2CH2NHCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (NNN silane) were used. In the co-condensation method, amino-functionalized MCM-41 was hydrothermally synthesized by using hexadecyltrimethylammnonium bromide (C16TMABr), tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) and the mixture of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and the amino-organoalkoxysilane at 373K for 4 days. The surfactant in the as-synthesized sample was removed by a solvent extraction method. The amino-functionalized MCM-41 obtained with N, NN and NNN silanes were designated as x-dN-, x-dNN- or x-dNNN-MCM-41, respectively, where x was the proportion of the amino-organoalkoxysilane in the Si sources. On the other hand, in the post-synthesis grafting method, a purely inorganic MCM-41 was first synthesized and then calcined. Thus obtained MCM-41 was stirred vigorously in dry toluene containing an amino-organoalkoxysilane under reflux conditions. The loading of amino moieties on the surface was changed by varying the amount of amino-organoalkoxysilane added. The obtained functionalized MCM-41 with N, NN and NNN silanes via the post-synthesis grafting method were designated as gN-, gNN- or gNNN-MCM-41, respectively. 2.1.2 Structural properties Fig. 2(a) shows the XRD patterns of x-dN-MCM-41 after the extraction of the surfactant [34]. The XRD patterns of x-dN-MCM-41 exhibited a single broad peak when x was over 0.2, indicating that the array of meso channels of dN-MCM-41 became disordered. When the proportion x was over 0.7, no precipitate was formed even after aging at 373K for 4 days. Fig. 2(b) and (c) shows the XRD patterns of x-dNN- and x-dNNN-MCM-41 after the extraction of the surfactant, respectively; they followed the same trend in the reflection patterns as dN-MCM-41 [34]. Namely, the proportion x was increased to over 0.3, the patterns exhibited only single broad peak, and when the proportion x was over 0.5, no precipitate was formed. The d 100 spacing of the surfactant-extracted x-dN-MCM-41 was increased with an increase in the proportion of N silane (Table 1) [34]. This change is contradictory to the observation on the functionalization of MCM-41 with vinyltriethoxysilane by Ozin and his co-workers [28] and on the mercaptopropyl-functionalized wormhole mesostructure (MP-HMS) by Pinnavaia and his co-workers [30]. They have proposed that the shrinkage in cell dimensions may be due to a strong interaction between non-polar organic groups and the tails of the surfactant molecules. Such hydrophobic interactions would draw the organic precursors further into the micelles, leading to the decline in the d 100 spacing. On the other hand, in dN-MCM-41, when the silica-surfactant composites are formed in the micellar solution, hydrophobic interactions between the terminal organic moiety of the organoalkoxysilane and the long alkyl chain of the surfactant would be interrupted by the presence of hydrophilic amino groups, and therefore the organic moiety would not be drawn into the micelles, resulting in the increased d 100 spacing. However, in dNN- and dNNN-MCM-41, the d 100 spacing was slightly decreased with increasing proportion x (Table 1) and the peak intensity attributed to 100 reflection was decreased with increasing proportion x as a result of the decrease in the mesophase order. The XRD patterns of gN-MCM-41 with different loading amounts of N silane reveal that the peak intensity and position of the dominant d 100 reflection was hardly changed when the loading of N silane was increased (Table 2) [34]. In the XRD reflection patterns of gNN- and gNNN-MCM-41 followed the same trend as gN-MCM-41. 2.1.3 Content of amino groups The content of the amino group in the solid was evaluated by two methods; one is the CHN elemental analysis and the other is the argentometric titration technique. The CHN elemental analysis gave the total amount of amino groups in the solid. On the other hand, the argentometric titration with AgNO3 following neutralization with HCl gives the amount of amino groups on the surface of mesopores in the amino-functionalized MCM-41 [35]. The content of the amino group in the extracted 0.1-dN-MCM-41 determined by CHN elemental analysis and the argentometric titration was 0.83 and 0.76mmolg−1, respectively. This gap suggests that 8% of total N silane in the functionalized silica was not present on the surface but in the silica wall. The percentage of unexposed amino moieties was increased with increasing proportion of N silane in the Si sources; 18% of N silane in the extracted 0.4-dN-MCM-41 was unexposed to the surface. The percentage of unexposed amino moieties was influenced by the type of amino-organoalkoxysilanes; 35 and 41% of NN and NNN silanes in the functionalized silicas at x =0.4 were unexposed to the surface, respectively. The surface density of amino groups immobilized on the surface is calculated by using the BET surface area (S BET) of the functionalized MCM-41 and the content of the amino group determined by the argentometric titration. When the proportion x of N, NN and NNN silanes was 0.4, the surface densities of the amino group are 1.38, 1.63 and 2.41, respectively (Table 1); the surface densities of N, NN and NNN silanes are 1.38, 0.82 and 0.80nm−2, respectively. The surface density of NN and NNN silanes is lower than that of N silane, indicating that the size and the number of amino group in the amino-organoalkoxysilanes strongly influenced the functionalization of silica by the direct co-condensation method. Fig. 3(a) shows the 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the surfactant-extracted MCM-41, 0.4-dN-MCM-41, 0.4-dNN-MCM-41 and 0.4-dNNN-MCM-41 [34]. The peaks at −58 and −66ppm attributed to T2 and T3 silicons (T n =R-Si(OSi) n (OH)3− n ), respectively, and the peaks at −92, −100 and −109ppm attributed to Q2, Q3 and Q4 silicons (Q n =Si(OSi) n (OH)4– n ), respectively, indicating the presence of SiC bonds. The ratio of silicon bound to the organic group to total silicon, ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n ), is shown in Table 1. The ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n ) of the extracted 0.1-dN-MCM-41 was 8.8 Simol%, being close to the starting gel composition. The percentage of N silane included, however, was decreased with increasing x; the ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n ) at x =0.4 was 23 Simol%, namely only 57% of N silane introduced into the mother gel was incorporated. The ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n ) of 0.4-dNN- and 0.4-dNNN-MCM-41 was 17.0 and 7.8mol% Si, respectively, indicating that only 43 and 20% of NN and NNN silanes in the starting mother gel were present in the functionalized silica. These results suggest that NN and NNN silanes are difficult to condense into the siloxane network due to the larger size of hydrophilic terminal organic moiety in these silanes than that in N silane. It has been observed that the high content of organoalkoxysilanes in the Si sources hampered the condensation of silicates to form the framework because the rate of hydrolysis of organoalkoxysilanes is slower under basic conditions than that of tetraalkoxysilanes due to the higher basicity at the silicon center [36]. For gN-, gNN and gNNN-MCM-41 at the maximum level of the silylation, the surface density of the amino group is 1.83, 3.23 and 6.24nm−2, respectively; the surface density of N, NN and NNN silanes on the surface was 1.8, 1.6 and 2.1nm−2, respectively, indicating that the surface densities of N, NN and NNN silanes anchored to the surface silanol groups were almost the same, irrespective of the size of the amino-organoalkoxysilanes. Fig. 3(b) shows the 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the MCM-41 samples before and after functionalization with N, NN and NNN silanes at the maximum level of the silylation. The ratio of silicon bound to the organic group to total silicon, ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n ), of gN, gNN- and gNNN-MCM-41 at the maximum level of the silylation was 20.6, 19.2 and 17.9 Simol %, respectively (Table 2). This estimate indicates that the degree of the functionalization by silylation with N, NN and NNN silanes was not markedly dependent on the type of the amino-organoalkoxysilanes used. The molecular size of N, NN and NNN silanes is estimated at approximately 0.9, 1.3 and 1.7nm, respectively. Considering the pore size of purely inorganic MCM-41 (ca.=3.6nm), NN and NNN silanes as well as N silane would be easily diffused in the mesopore. 2.1.4 Adsorptive performance Co2+ (d 7 ) and Fe3+ (d 5 ) cations in solution are easily captured by amino-ligands [37–39] and they form tetrahedral and octahedral complexes coordinated with NH2, Cl− and H2O ligands [39]. Therefore, the adsorption experiments of Co2+ and Fe3+ were conducted in order to comparatively investigate the activity and the location of the amino-organic moieties introduced into MCM-41 via the direct co-condensation and post-synthesis grafting methods. As a control, unfunctionalized pure MCM-41 was tested for cation binding under similar conditions. The adsorptions of Co2+ and Fe3+ on purely inorganic MCM-41 were negligible. The surface density of Co2+ and Fe3+ adsorbed on dN-, dNN- and dNNN-MCM-41 was increased with an increase in the surface density of the amino group regardless of the type of the amino-organoalkoxysilanes (Fig. 4(a) and (b)) [34], indicating that the amino groups effectively worked as adsorption sites for the metal cations. The molar ratio of N/Co was decreased with increasing amino groups; the ratios of N/Co in 0.4-dN, 0.4-dNN- and 0.4-dNNN-MCM-41 were 6.1, 4.5 and 3.1, respectively (Table 3). On the other hand, the ratio of N/Fe was almost constant (ca.=3.0) regardless of the content of amino groups. It was implied that Co2+ cation could form tetrahedral and/or octahedral complexes with an unspecific number of amino groups as ligands and that one Fe3+ cation could be complexed by three amino groups. The surface density of Co2+ adsorbed by gN-MCM-41 was increased with an increase in the surface density of the amino groups. However, the surface density of Co2+ adsorbed by gNN-MCM-41 and gNNN-MCM-41 was not increased with an increase in the surface density of the amino group (Fig. 5(a)) [34]; when gNN- and gNNN-MCM-41 at the maximum level of the silylation were used, the molar ratio of N/Co was considerably high (ca. 9 and 51, respectively, see Table 3), exhibiting that the amino group did not work as adsorption sites for Co2+ effectively. The surface densities of Fe3+ adsorbed on gN- and gNN-MCM-41 were increased with an increase in the surface density of the amino groups. The amount of Fe3+ adsorbed on gNNN-MCM-41, however, was decreased with an increase in the surface density of the amino group, as the adsorption of Co2+ on gNNN-MCM-41 (Fig. 5(b)) [34]. 2.1.5 State and reactivity of amino groups The fact that the gNN- and gNNN-MCM-41 materials did not capture Co2+ and Fe3+ despite the high surface density of the amino group gives us profound implications. Co2+ and Fe3+ cations in the solution form complexes with ligands of 2-propanol, H2O and Cl− molecules. Considering that the molecular sizes of such complexes are approximately 0.8 and 0.9nm, respectively, they would be easy to approach amino groups fixed in the pore since the pore size of gN-, gNN- and gNNN-MCM-41 (ca. about 2.7–3.1nm, shown in Table 2) is large enough for them to diffuse in the pore. Nevertheless, the content of Co2+ and Fe3+ adsorbed was not increased as the surface density of amino groups was increased. It is conceivable that the amino-organoalkoxysilanes react dominantly with surface silanol groups located at the openings of channels and/or on the extra surface. If this is the case, the amino-organic moieties concentrated near the entrance of the pore would restrict the penetration of the organoalkoxysilanes into the pore, resulting in heterogeneous distribution of amino-organic moieties in the pores. Moreover, near the entrance of the pore would be congested with the amino-organic moieties and as a result the effective pore size would be decreased. Such environments would lead to a decrease in opportunities for Co2+ and Fe3+ to interact with amino groups located inside. Furthermore, amino groups forming a certain domain can easily interact with adjacent amino groups by hydrogen bond, leading to the decrease in reactivity [40]. In the direct co-condensation method, the amino-organosilanes were introduced into the mother gel with TEOS simultaneously, leading to a homogeneous distribution of amino-organic moieties in the silica framework though amino groups are partly unavoidably present inside the silica wall. On the other hand, in the post-synthesis grafting method, all amino-organic moieties introduced into the silica are anchored on the surface silanol group by covalent bonds. This method may be advantageous when the goal is to maximize the number of amino group on the surface. However, one disadvantage of the post-synthesis grafting method is that the distribution of the organic moiety on the surface was uncontrollable. McKittrick and Jones reported the preparation of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica containing isolated amines with homogenous distribution on the surface by a molecular patterning technique [40]. Although this is different technique from the conventional one, the content of amino-organic moieties was considerably low (ca.=0.39mmolg−1). A critical difference in the adsorption of Co2+ and Fe3+ on the amino groups was observed between the direct co-condensation and post-synthesis grafting methods. This is caused by different modes of surface attachment and the location of amino groups; the functionalized silica prepared by the direct co-condensation would have a homogeneous distribution of amino-organic moieties on the silica wall. On the other hand, in the functionalized MCM-41 by the grafting method, most amino-organic moieties may concentrate near the openings of channels and/or on the external surface. 2.2 Preparation of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica via anionic surfactant-templated route The formation of mesostructured materials has been promoted by a micelle-templating method including electrostatic charge-matching and electrically neutral pathways using surfactants as an SDA [5,6]. The use of anionic surfactants as an SDA for the synthesis of the mesoporous silica has attracted considerable attention, because anionic surfactants have several advantages as compared with cationic and non-ionic surfactants. Anionic surfactants are used in greater volume than any other surfactant, and they have high detergency and biodegradability. In addition, many different varieties of anionic surfactants are easily available [41]. However, the synthesis of mesoporous silica by using an anionic surfactant had been unsuccessful for long time. 2.2.1 Anionic surfactant templated mesoporous silica, AMS Since 2003, the synthesis of the anionic surfactant templated mesoporous silica, AMS, has been developed [42–46]. The use of anionic surfactants as SDAs for the formation of the mesostructured silica-micelle composite has been designated as the “S− N+∼I− pathway” that is promoted by utilization of an organoalkoxysilane containing amino groups such as 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), where S−, N+ and I− are negatively charged surfactants, positively charged amino groups and negatively charged silicates, respectively. Since the dissociation constant pK a of the amino group in APTES is about 10.6 at 298K, a considerable number of amino groups is protonated and so can interact with the anionic surfactant head group, if pH is below about 10. If this is the case, APTES works as a part of SDA. Therefore, we named APTES “co-structure-directing agent” (CSDA). The direct electrostatic interaction between the positively charged amino groups in APTES and the negatively charged head groups in the anionic surfactant is a driving force in the “S− N+∼I− pathway” for forming the silica-micelle composite. By optimizing the combination of the SDA and CSDA, and controlling the synthesis conditions, various well-ordered mesophases have been successfully prepared [43–46]. In addition to APTES, which is a base, 3-trimethylammoniopropyltrimethoxysilane (TMAPS) chloride, which is a quaternized ammonium salt, is useful as a CSDA. Furthermore, in addition to salt-type surfactants, acid-type surfactants are suitable as SDAs. Well-ordered AMS materials can be synthesized by double decomposition and neutralization (Fig. 6) [43]. If a salt type of anionic surfactant is used as the SDA, a salt type of CSDA should be used. In this case, the SDA and CSDA can interact by a double decomposition mechanism. On the other hand, if an acid type of anionic surfactants is used as the SDA, a base type of CSDA should be used. In this case, the SDA and CSDA can interact by a neutralization mechanism. The alkoxysilane moieties of APTES and TMAPS are co-condensed with tetraalkoxysilane, e.g. TEOS, to be assembled subsequently to form the silica framework. The trimethylene groups of APTES and TMAPS covalently tether the silicon atom incorporated into the framework to the head group of the anionic surfactant. Up to date, series AMS-1 to AMS-10 have been developed [47–49]. 2.2.2 Structural differences between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41 As described above, a novel synthetic route to mesoporous silicas using anionic surfactants involves the use of CSDAs such as TMAPS and APTES under alkaline conditions. These mesoporous structures are synthetically interesting for both structural diversity, including chiral properties, and for the potential to functionalize the pore surface by removing the surfactant by solvent extraction. The calcination of as-synthesized AMS leads to the removal of both the surfactant and organic moieties derived from the CSDA, resulting in purely inorganic silica. Removal of the surfactant by acid extraction results in mesoporous silica with aminopropyl groups (Fig. 7). Thus obtained amino-functionalized AMS can be applied in solid-base catalysis, adsorption, drug delivery, etc., in a similar manner to amino-functionalized MCM-41. Therefore, the differences in the state and activity of the amino groups on the mesopores in the amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas synthesized via anionic and cationic surfactants templated routes were investigated. For this purpose, the amino-functionalized AMS sample was synthesized with APTES and lauric acid sodium salt (LAS) as CSDA and SDA, respectively [50]. As a control, amino-functionalized MCM-41 was also synthesized by the direct co-condensation method using the typical cationic surfactant dodecyltrimethylammonium bromide, APTES and TEOS [34]. Thus obtained amino-functionalized samples were designated as x-APS-AMS and x-APS-MCM-41, respectively, where x was the proportion of APTES in the Si sources. The XRD patterns of as-synthesized x-APS-AMS (x =0.1–0.6) showed only one peak in the range of 2θ =1.5–2.0°. Fig. 8(a) illustrates the XRD patterns of surfactant-extracted x-APS-AMS (x =0.1–0.6), which exhibit a broad peak, suggesting that x-APS-AMS is mesostructured silica with low regularity [50]. When the proportion of APTES was increased up to 0.4, the intensity of the peak was increased and its position was gradually shifted to a higher angle; the d spacing was decreased. This is likely because the electrostatic interaction between cationic amino groups and anionic surfactant head groups is increased with increasing proportion of APTES. When only TEOS was used as a silica source, no precipitate was obtained, directly due to the difficulty in interaction between the surfactant-micelles and the silica species as well as the lack of catalysis for the hydrolysis of TEOS followed by condensation of the resultant products; the attempts to synthesize mesoporous silica by using primary alkylamine and quaternary ammonium salts in place of APTES in combination with TEOS were unsuccessful. These results suggest that the presence of both aminopropyl groups directly attached to Si atom and TEOS in the synthesis gel containing anionic surfactants is indispensable for the formation of AMS. On the other hand, when the proportion of APTES was 0.6, the mesostructure was deteriorated. It is concluded that the optimum proportion of APTES in the silica sources to obtain the functionalized-mesostructured AMS is between 0.2 and 0.5. Fig. 8(b) shows the 29Si MAS NMR spectra of surfactant-extracted x-APS-AMS samples (x =0.2–0.5) [50]. The peaks at −52, −58 and −61ppm attributed to T1, T2 and T3 silicons (T n =R-Si(OSi) n (OH)3− n ), respectively, and the peaks at −92, −101 and −109ppm attributed to Q2, Q3 and Q4 silicons (Q n =Si(OSi) n (OH)4− n ), respectively were observed in all the spectra, indicating that SiC species derived from APTES were present in the surfactant-extracted AMS. The ratio of SiOH bonds to the total silicons, ΣSiOH/ΣSi (=Σ(Q3 +2Q2 +3Q3 +T2 +2T1)/Σ(T n +Q n )), gives us information about the degree of the silica condensation (Table 4(a) and (b)). The ratio, ΣSiOH/ΣSi, for AMS samples, was lower than those for MCM-41; when the proportion of APTES in the reactant was 0.2, the ratio was found to be 0.38 and 0.60, respectively. This difference in the degree of the silica condensation might be attributed to the difference in pH of the mother gel; the pH of the mother gel at the synthesis of AMS and MCM-41 was 10.0 and 13.1, respectively. The synthesis conditions for AMS are clearly advantageous to the progress of condensation of silicates to form siloxane networks than those for MCM-41. The ratio of SiC bonds to the total silicons, ΣSiC/ΣSi (=ΣT n /Σ(T n +Q n )), gives us information about the degree of the incorporation of APTES into the silica framework (Table 4(a) and (b)) [50]. When the proportion of APS in the silica sources was low (ex. x =0.1 and 0.2), there was no significant difference in the ratio of ΣSiC/ΣSi between the AMS and MCM-41samples. However, as the proportion of APTES was increased, we observed the significant difference in the ratio between the two methods of preparation of the materials was increased significantly. When the proportion of APTES in the reactant was 0.5, the ratio of the AMS product was found to be 0.44, being fairly close to the ratio of the reactants. On the other hand, in the case of MCM-41, the ratio, ΣSiC/ΣSi, of the product was found to be 0.27; in other words, only half of APTES added to the reactant was incorporated into the MCM-41 framework. When the proportion of APTES in the silica sources was high, APTES was easily incorporated into the AMS framework but hardly into the MCM-41 framework. It has been observed that for the cationic surfactant templating route the high content of organoalkoxysilanes in the silica sources hampered the condensation of silicates to form the silica framework [36]. In this study, the same tendency was observed; the ratio of ΣSiOH/ΣSi for AMS samples was increased with an increase in the proportion of APTES in the silica sources (Table 4(b)). However, in the case of AMS, the presence of the APTES would not significantly affect the condensation of silicate. 2.2.3 Difference in exposure ratio of amino groups between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41 As described above, although the CHN elemental analysis technique is used to estimate the content of the organic groups, it gives the content of all amino groups in the bulk. On the other hand, the argentometric titration technique can offer information about the content of amino groups only on the surface [34,35]. The comparison of the content of amino groups between the CHN analysis and the titration would give a definitive evidence for the location of the amino groups. The comparative results of determination of the amino groups in x-APS-AMS and x-APS-MCM-41 are summarized in Table 4(a) and (b), respectively [50]. The contents of the amino groups in the AMS samples determined by the two methods were almost equal, regardless of the proportion of APTES. Here, we defined “exposure ratio” as “N content determined by the titration/N content determined by the CHN analysis”. For AMS samples, this “exposure ratio” was always over 94%, indicating that almost all the amino groups were exposed to the surfaces, not occluded in the silica wall. When the proportion of APTES was 0.5, the surface density of the amino group reached about 3nm−2. For MCM-41, the contents of the amino groups determined by the two methods were almost equal at the proportion of APTES of 0.1, as shown in Table 4(b). However, as the proportion of APTES was increased, the difference in the content of the amino groups determined by the two methods increased; the exposure ratio was decreased with increasing proportion of APTES. When the proportion of APTES was 0.4, about 20% of the amino groups were occluded in the silica wall. The maximum surface density was only 1.4aminomoieties/nm−2. 2.2.4 Difference in the reactivity of amino groups between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41 Fig. 9 shows the time-course of the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde (1) with ethyl cyanoacetate (2) catalyzed by 0.3-APS-AMS and 0.3-APS-MCM-41. Both catalysts exhibited a selectivity near 100% for ethyl α-cyanocinnamate (3). Surprisingly, there was a marked difference in the activity between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41, although the contents of amino groups were not exactly the same. Amino-functionalized AMS gave the product 3 in high yield under mild conditions (30°C). On the other hand, amino-functionalized MCM-41 did show a low activity for the reaction, although the amount of the exposed amino group determined by the argentometric titration reached about 60% of amino-functionalized AMS. In terms of the turnover frequency (TOF) shown in Fig. 9 [50], it is obvious that aminopropyl moieties tethered on AMS are advantageous. No reaction took place when the inorganic MCM-41 after the acid-extraction of surfactant followed by the basification with diluted NH3 solution was used as a catalyst, indicating that there were no active sites other than the tethered organic moieties. Thus, the observed great difference in the reactivity might be mainly attributed to the state of aminopropyl groups exposed to the surface, not the difference in mesoporosities such as a specific surface area and pore size. Fajula and Brunel reported on the reaction mechanism of this Knoevenagel condensation by using MCM-41 grafted aminopropyl group [51]; this reaction is initiated by the interaction between amino groups and benzaldehyde, leading to the transient formation of the imine intermediate enhanced by primary amines. The pendant type aminopropyl moieties protruding above the surface, as shown in Fig. 10(a), will efficiently work as active sites for the reaction. Considering that the ratio of ΣSiOH/ΣSi for 0.3-APS-AMS and 0.3-APS-MCM-41 was found to be 0.37 and 0.63, respectively (Table 4) [50], in the case of AMS, the pendant type aminopropyl groups would be dominant species. On the other hand, in the case of MCM-41, parts of basic amino groups on the surface would strongly interact with slightly acidic silanol groups on the surface through a hydrogen bond, as shown in Fig. 10(b), probably due to the abundant surface silanol groups on the MCM-41 samples [40]. Amino groups closely interacting with acidic silanol groups might show less activity as a base-catalyst, resulting in the lower yield of the Knoevenagel condensation products. 2.2.5 Difference in the state and location of amino groups between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41 These experimental results described above provide definitive information about the difference in the sate and location of amino groups between amino-functionalized AMS and MCM-41. The aminopropyl groups in the MCM-41 synthesized via the cationic surfactant templating route cannot penetrate into surfactant micelles because the hydrophilic amino groups would be repelled by the hydrophobic alkyl chains inside the micelles. Instead, parts of the amino groups could be occluded inside the silica wall [34]. On the other hand, almost all the aminopropyl moieties in AMS were present on the surface with homogenous distribution, probably due to the direct electrostatic interaction between the cationic amino groups in APS and the anionic surfactant head groups of the micelles (Fig. 11) [50]. Thus, functionalized AMS with homogeneously distributed pendent amino groups on the surface of the mesoporous silica has potential uses as catalysts, adsorbents, ligands to immobilize complexes, etc. 3 Solid-base catalyst Much attention has been paid to amino-functionalized mesoporous materials used as heterogeneous solid-base catalysts. The performance of the heterogeneous catalysts has been investigated for epoxidation and carbon–carbon bond-forming reactions, including the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, the aldol condensation reaction, the Michael addition reaction, the Claisen–Schmidt condensation reaction, the nitroaldol condensation reaction and the self condensation. These efforts have been excellently summarized in reviews [13–15,52,53]. This part gives an overview on the recent development of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica as solid-base catalyst. 3.1 Silicate-organic composite materials (SOCMs) For the synthesis of high-silica porous silicates, quaternary ammonium cations are very often used as SDA. The silicate-organic composite materials (SOCMs for short) are obtained as precursors followed by the removal of SDA by means of calcination or extraction to give porosity (Fig. 12) [54]. It is logical to use SDA-free materials in order to utilize their large surface area inside pores. Therefore, the immobilization of organic functional groups on the internal surface of porous silicates to obtain organic-functionalized molecular sieves (OFMSs) is a conventional and common idea for developing heterogeneous catalytic systems. On the other hand, no attention had been paid to the catalytic activity of as-synthesized SOCM, which is the precursor obtained during the synthesis, until we found the high catalytic activity of this non-conventional type of catalyst [54,55]. 3.1.1 Preparation of SOCMs (CTMA+)-[Si]-MCM-41 denotes as-synthesized pure-silica MCM-41 synthesized by using cetyltrimethylammonium (CTMA+) cation as SDA [2,56]. On the basis of elemental analysis, the amount of CTMA+ cation occluded in the (CTMA+)-[Si]-MCM-41 is 1.65mmolg−1. Microporous SOCMs were also prepared and tested. (TEA+)-[Al]-BEA denotes as-synthesized aluminosilicate beta synthesized by using tetraethylammonium (TEA+) cation as SDA. As-synthesized aluminosilicate ZSM-12 synthesized by using TEA+ [57] and as-synthesized pure-silica ZSM-12 synthesized by using triethylmethylammonium (MTEA+) [58] were designated as (TEA+)-[Al]-MTW and (MTEA+)-[Si]-MTW, respectively. The as-synthesized aluminosilicate beta was synthesized by using tetraethylammonium (TEA+) [59]. (TEA+F−)-[Si]-BEA is an as-synthesized, pure-silica beta synthesized by the method of Camblor et al., in which the number of defect sites is very low [60,61]. Part of (CTMA+)-[Si]-MCM-41 and (TEA+)-[Al]-BEA were calcined at 550°C in air to give [Si]-MCM-41 and [Al]-BEA, respectively. The detailed synthetic procedures have been described elsewhere [62]. As a control, OFMS type catalyst was prepared by grafting APTES on [Si]-MCM-41 (AP-MCM-41). 3.1.2 Catalytic properties of SOCMs Catalytic performance of these catalysts for the Michael reaction was evaluated (Fig. 13) [54]. Results of the reaction of 4-methoxylphenylmethylideneacetophenone (1c) with diethyl malonate (2a) using various catalysts are listed in Table 5 [54]. The reaction of 1c with 2a readily occurred when catalyzed by the SOCM catalyst. (CTMA+)-[Si]-MCM-41 showed a high catalytic activity and the reaction proceeded smoothly under mild conditions to give the desired product 3ca in high to moderate yields (entries 2–5). On the other hand, calcined, SDA-free materials such as [Si]-MCM-41 showed no catalytic activity (entry 6). CTMA+Br− did not show any activity, either (entry 7). The reaction catalyzed by (TEA+)-[Al]-BEA gave 3ca although the yield was not high (entry 8). These results suggest that the complexation between silicate and quaternary ammonium is necessary for the high activity. However, it is not always true because the composite (TEA+F−)-[Si]-BEA was not active at all (entry 9). 3.1.3 Solid-state NMR of the SOCM catalyst Solid-state 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the as-synthesized MCM-41 and BEA-type materials are shown in Fig. 14 [54]. The resonances corresponding to Si(3-OSi, 1-OH), i.e. Q3, are obvious in the spectra of catalytically active (CTMA+)-[Si]-MCM-41 and (TEA+)-[Al]-BEA, whereas only a weak Si(3-OSi, 1-OH) resonance peak can be seen in the spectrum of catalytically inactive (TEA+F−)-[Si]-BEA, which is consistent with the reported results [63–66]. Therefore, it is suggested that the basic (SiO)3SiO−(+NR4) moieties in the composite materials play some roles for catalysis. However, there is no quantitative relationship between the activity and the intensity of the Q3 peak. Among the bulk species, only the (SiO)3SiO− species which are accessible by the substrates could take part in the reaction. It is interesting to note that the presence of ion pair SiO− +NR4 is taken for granted as far as ‘quaternary ammonium’ cations (+NR4) are occluded in the ‘all silica’ frameworks. On the other hand, a rapid equilibrium (SiOH+H2NR⇆SiO− +H3N+R) is expected in the OFMS (AP-functionalized) situation. The presence of H3N+R (and SiO− as a possible active site) has been suggested by using XPS by Brunel et al. [67]. 3.1.4 Mechanistic consideration A plausible mechanism is shown in Fig. 15 [54]. In general, this reaction starts from the abstraction of a proton by a base (B−) from the active methylene compound such as diethyl malonate (step 1). The carbanion thus formed (the concentration would not always be high) attacks the β-carbon of α,β-unsaturated ketone such as a chalcone derivative to form a carbon–carbon bond (step 2). The last step (step 3) consists of the formation of the final product and the regeneration of base. If these steps operate completely, the catalytic cycle continues. B−M+ in the scheme corresponds to the (SiO)3SiO−(+NR4) ion pair for the SOCM catalyst. It is possible that the steps 1–3 proceed on the solid surface or in its close proximity. In such a case, this catalytic system is regarded as heterogeneous. It would also be possible that the M+(=+NR4) is in the bulk liquid phase during the step 2. If this is the case, then this catalytic system cannot be considered as perfectly heterogeneous. In both cases, however, this system would act as if it were totally heterogeneous when the step 3 operates properly. Incomplete returning of the +NR4 cation to the solid would cause the loss of organic content of the catalyst. In the polar solvent, the step 3 would not operate properly, and the +NR4 could be pulled out into the solution, leading to the loss of activity upon the repeated use. Therefore, the use of non-polar solvent is rather recommended. A possibility that a very low concentration of OH− helps the catalysis in this reaction still remains. However, it was turned out that the active species are absent in the liquid phase after the reaction. Therefore, OH− species such as CTMA+OH− cannot be responsible for the major activity. From a different point of view, the use of high concentration OH− (including a Brönsted base-immobilized catalyst [68]) is not recommended in this reaction system because of the following reasons. First, it would cause the hydrolysis of the ester group, reducing the yield. For the SOCM catalyst, such kind of hydrolyzed products have never been observed. Second, high concentration of OH− is generally to be avoided in the light of the instability of silica framework under highly alkaline conditions. 3.2 Effects of morphology and pore size Park et al. has extensively investigated into the morphological control of SBA-15 and successfully developed the amino-functionalized SBA-15 type mesoporous silica having nanostructured hexagonal platelet morphology that enhanced the catalytic performances in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate [69]. Yano et al. have studied on the synthesis and application of the mesoporous silica spheres [70–72]. The effects of pore size on the base catalysis have been studied by using amino-functionalized monodispersed mesoporous silica spheres (NH2-MMSS) [73]. NH2-MMSS with similar particle diameters (560–600nm) and different pore sizes (0–2.66nm) were successfully prepared (C x -MS, x =10, 12, 16 and 18) by changing the carbon length of n-alkyltrimethylammonium halide surfactant (C x TMACl, x =10–18) and/or the synthetic conditions. To further expand the pore size, uncalcined C x -MS was suspended in C22TMACl water–ethanol solution, and the mixture was sealed and placed in an oven at 353K for 7 days without stirring (C x -PS-MS). The aminopropyl moiety was introduced onto the mesopores by a post-synthesis grafting method using 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (C x -MS-AP and C x PS-MS-AP). As a control, the aminopropyl moiety was grafted on FSM-16, which is a mesoporous silica having irregular shape, and monodispersed silica spheres without pores (FSM-16-AP and SS-AP). The pore sizes of the C x -MS-AP samples were found to be 0, 1.34, 1.53 and 1.89 for x =10, 14, 16 and 18, respectively. C18-PS-MS-AP has the largest pore size of 2.66nm. The pore size of FSM-16-AP was found to be 1.98nm. The catalytic activities of C x -MS-AP were tested on the nitroaldol condensation of nitromethane and benzaldehyde derivatives. Table 6 summarizes the pore size, the initial rate and TON (turnover number) determined from data for 1h reaction for various catalysts [73], indicating that TON was largely affected by the pore size of MMSS. C16-MSAP (pore size: 1.53nm) and C18-MS-AP (pore size: 1.89nm) showed high catalytic activity. The relationship between the pore size of particles and TON for nitroaldol condensation over C18-MS-AP is shown in Fig. 16 [73]. The optimum pore size for the nitroaldol condensation shifted to a higher value by increasing the number of substituent groups in the reactant. They have claimed that the reaction mostly proceeds inside the mesopores and that the optimum pore size for the NH2-MMSS was affected by the type and number of the substituent groups on the reactants. Yano et al. also reported the effect of the particle diameter of amino-functionalized MMSS on the base catalytic activity [74]. The amino-functionalized MMSS catalysts with different particle diameters ranging from 310 to 780nm were prepared by changing the methanol/water ratio or by adding extra silica source via a direct co-condensation method using tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) and 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS); e.g., the catalyst in the proportion of APTMS/(TMOS+APTMS) of 5%, and 490nm in the particle diameter was designated as MS-AP5%-490nm. The results of the nitroaldol reactions of 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde with nitromethane over the amino-functionalized MMSS catalysts with different particle diameters are summarized in Table 7 [74], which reveals that the catalytic activity is dependent on the particle diameters when they are in the range between 490 and 780nm, and that the smaller diameter leads to the higher activity. This is because most of the surfaces of the particles consist of mesopores, then the smaller the particle, the greater the number of pores that are accessible per unit weight. However, the activity actually was decreased for the smallest diameter of particle, MS-AP5%-310nm. This happened probably because, with the smaller diameter, the aggregation of particles becomes a significant factor. Therefore, sonification was performed prior to the reaction in order to prevent aggregation. As a result, the activity recovered to the same level as that of MS-AP5%-490nm. The catalytic activity of MS-AP5%-780nm exhibited the same levels with or without sonification. 3.3 Introduction of additional function Asefa et al. investigated the effect of additional organic groups including ureidopropyl, 3-mercaptopropyl, and methyl groups on the aminopropyl-functionalized MCM-41 on the catalytic performance in the Henry reaction [75]. Fig. 17 shows the multifunctional mesoporous catalysts containing various concentrations of 3-aminopropyl catalytic groups, residual silanols and secondary organic groups [75]. Such catalysts were applied to the selective catalysis of either hydrophilic or hydrophobic reactants in the Henry reaction. They concluded that the addition of secondary organic functional groups inside mesoporous channels provided the materials with suitable surface properties to allow preferential reaction of hydrophilic or hydrophobic reactants. Bae et al. reported the effect of pore structure of amine-functionalized mesoporous silica-supported rhodium catalysts on 1-octene hydroformylation; amine-functionalized mesoporous silicas with different pore sizes (MCM-41, SBA-15 and amorphous silica) were prepared by using a post-synthesis method using 6-amino-4-azahexylmethyldimethoxysilane NH2CH2CH2NHCH2CH2CH2Si(CH3)(OCH3)2 (AEAPMDMS) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) and subsequently, rhodium was immobilized on the aminated mesoporous silica materials (Fig. 18) [76]. The Rh supported amino-functionalized SBA-15 catalysts gave a higher yield of aldehyde in the 1-octene hydroformylation compared to the simple amino-functionalized SBA-15 due to an electron-donating effect of the amine ligand. Very recently, Lang et al. also reported the effectiveness of the immobilization of Rh-P complex on the amino-functionalized MCM-41 for the one-pot synthesis of 2-ethylhexenal from propene [77]. 3.4 Mesoporous silicon oxynitride materials In 2001, El Haskouri et al. reported the preparation of ordered mesoporous N-containing silicas (i.e., mesoporous silicon oxynitrides) having a high surface area and regular hexagonal pore size distribution [78]. Inaki et al. also developed mesoporous N-containing silicas by ammonia grafting; evacuated FSM-16 was exposed to gaseous NH3 in a closed system [79]. They reported that NH3-treated mesoporous silica (FSM-16) contains SiNH2 sites which exhibited a basic catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation; SiNH2 and SiOH pair sites formed at lower NH3-treatment temperatures exhibited a higher catalytic performance in comparison with SiNH2 single sites. The nitridation reaction occurs according to the following schemes: SiOH+NH3 → SiNH2 +H2O and/or SiOSi +NH3 → SiNHSi +H2O or SiNH2 + SiOH Following these reports, extensive researches on mesoporous silicon oxynitrides regarding the synthesis [80–84], the introduction mechanism [85] and the application as solid-base catalyst [86–88] have been conducted. In 2003, Xia and Mokaya reported the catalytic performance of mesoporous silicon oxynitride materials in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction [86]. The calcined and as-synthesized MCM-48 samples were subjected to thermal treatment at 900°C in a flow of NH3 gas, resulting in the N-containing materials, which were designated as N-MCM-48A and N-MCM-48B, respectively. The N contents in the N-MCM-48A and N-MCM-48B samples were 11.4 and 14.7wt%, respectively. The XRD patterns and N2 sorption studies confirmed that both samples have good structural ordering. To explore the catalytic properties of the MCM-48 silicon oxynitride materials, the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and malononitrile was performed at 60°C under an inert atmosphere (Fig. 19). Although pure silica MCM-48 exhibited negligible catalytic activity, the N-MCM-48 materials were active in this reaction. After the reaction time of 3h, N-MCM-48A and N-MCM-48B achieved the conversions of 78% and 96%, respectively, to give 1,1-dicyanophenylethylene with a selectivity of 100%. The higher conversion over N-MCM-48B is consistent with its higher nitrogen content. Noteworthily, the catalytic activity achieved by the N-MCM-48 materials was higher than that of the commercially available MgO catalyst. Very recently, Ogura and his co-workers developed a strong base catalyst that can accelerate the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with diethyl malonate [89]. Diethyl malonate is known as a much less reactive substrate than cyano group-containing active methylene compounds, and conventional amino-functionalized silicates have not been able to catalyze the reaction of benzaldehyde with diethyl malonate. Consistently, the SBA-15 with framework SiNHSi did not catalyze this reaction. Their strategy to break this limitation is very simple, methylation of a nitrogen-substituted mesoporous silica SBA-15 (Fig. 20). The framework SiNMeSi prepared by a simple methylation greatly enhanced the activity. To clarify the effect of the methylated nitrogens, a catalyst that was methylated but contained no amine bridges was also used. It is noteworthy that only methylated nitrogen-substituted SBA-15 (Me-NSBA) catalyzed the reaction, whereas the other samples showed almost no catalytic ability (Fig. 21). These results clearly show that the addition of methyl groups to nitrogen atoms in the framework greatly increased the basicity of the catalyst and that the catalytic activity was significantly increased by methylation. This result demonstrates a possible new type of base catalyst using nitrogen-substituted mesoporous silica materials. Thus, the mesoporous silicon oxynitrides will find applications in base catalysis and gas separation, environmental remediation and controlled delivery of chemicals. 4 Adsorbent 4.1 Toxic heavy metal ions The development of effective adsorbents for the removal of toxically heavy metal species from waste water has received considerable attention for environmental pollution control processes. Although various techniques for effectively removing toxically heavy metal ions have been developed, the adsorption is considered as a simple and facile technique, which is adaptive to personal and portable use for water supply; the adsorption techniques have been reported for the removal of pollutant metal cations by using activated carbon [90,91], polymer [92], zeolites [93,94] and clays [95,96]. Considerable efforts have been devoted to the preparation of mesoporous silica-based adsorbents due to their large surface area, well-defined pore size and pore shape and well-modified surface properties. In this application, the materials are generally required to exhibit specific binding sites for heavy metal ions. However, mesoporous silicas do not have such surface properties. Accordingly, an efficient approach has been developed so that functional groups are chemically immobilized onto the surfaces of mesopores. The functionalized hybrid materials show great adsorption capacity and specificity for metal ions. 4.1.1 Heavy metal cations In 1997, Feng et al. first reported the preparation of organic-functionalized mesoporous silica, MCM-41, with mercaptopropyl group, which is extremely efficient in removing mercury cation (Hg2+) and other heavy metal ions [97,98]. Mercier and Pinnavaia also developed an effective adsorbent for Hg2+ based on the thiol-functionalized mesoporous silica [99–101]. After these pioneering works, several functionalized mesoporous materials as adsorbent for removing heavy metal ions have been developed and amino-functionalized mesoporous silica has been also applied to adsorption of toxic ions. Thiol- and amino-functionalized SBA-15 silicas with uniform mesoporosities were prepared and employed for removing heavy metal ions from waste water; the thiolated SBA-15 adsorbent exhibited a higher complexation affinity for Hg2+, while the other metal ions (Cu2+, Zn2+, Cr3+ and Ni2+) showed exceptional binding ability to its aminated analog [102]. Mesoporous silica MCM-41 modified with 1-allyl-3-propylthiourea exhibited a high adsorption capacity toward mercury(II) ions and its regeneration can be accomplished under mild conditions, e.g., by washing with 10% thiourea aqueous solution [103]. Bois et al. reported the syntheses of the functionalized mesoporous silicas with 3-aminopropyl (H2N(CH2)3 ), [6-amino-4-azahexyl (H2N (CH2)2 NH(CH2)3 ), 9-amino-4,7-diazanonyl (H2N (CH2)2 NH (CH2)2 NH(CH2)3 ), and 3-mercaptopropyl (HS (CH2)3 ) groups by using dodecylamine as SDA via a direct co-condensation method, and their use as adsorbent for heavy metal ions from aqueous solutions [104]. The functionalized porous silicas synthesized with 6-amino-4-azahexyl and 9-amino-4,7-diazanonyl functions show high loading capacities for Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+ and the anion Cr(VI). The sample synthesized with a mercaptopropyl function has a high loading capacity for Cd2+. 4.1.2 Oxyanions In addition to toxically heavy metal cations, pollution by oxyanions, such as arsenate [105–107], chromate [108,109], selenate [110,111] and molybdate [112], in groundwater has been a serious and issue in the areas where drinkable water is obtained from well. Unlike many other heavy metals, these toxic elements often occur as tetrahedral oxyanions (e.g., arsenate, chromate, selenate and molybdate) in the hydrosphere [113,114]. The removals of the toxic oxyanions have been achieved by coprecipitation [115–118] reverse osmosis [119] or adsorbing colloid flotation (ACF) methods [120,121]. These methods generally need large and complicated facilities due to various equipments and reagents used in a series of treatments. The removal of tetrahedral toxic oxyanions by adsorption is much more difficult than that of the cations because the anions with a similar structure, such as nitrate, sulfate and phosphate, often coexist in nature with high concentrations. Although the adsorptive removal of the toxic oxyanions from solution by using conventional adsorbents, such as activated carbon [122,123], tannin gel [124], zeolite [125], iron oxides [126–129] and aluminum oxides [130], have been reported, they are not selective and effective. Searching effective adsorbents for the removal of the oxyanions is emergency and important for the environmental remedy. It has been reported that Cu-coordinated amino-functionalized mesoporous silica showed notable adsorption capacities for arsenate and chromate based on a cation-anion interaction [131]. We have designed and developed an effective adsorbent for the removal of oxyanions by using amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas. Amino-functionalized MCM-48 with 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (N silane), 6-amino-4-azahexyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2NHCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (NN silane) and 9-amino-4,7-diazanonyltrimethoxysilane, H2NCH2CH2NHCH2CH2NHCH2CH2CH2Si(OCH3)3, (NNN silane) via a post-synthesis grafting method were prepared. Then, the amino groups on the mesopores of MCM-48 were protonated. Thus prepared protonated amino-functionalized MCM-48 samples were designated as N-, NN- and NNN-MCM-48, respectively, and used as adsorbent for toxic oxyanions. As a control, fumed silica (Cab-O-Sil-M5, Cabot, BET surface area=170m2 g−1) was functionalized with NN silane and protonated by the same procedure. Fig. 22 shows the adsorption isotherms of chromate and arsenate, indicating that the adsorption capacities of NNN-MCM-48 reached 160 and 182mg/g-adsorbent for chromate (HCrO4 − and/or CrO4 2−) and arsenate (HAsO4 − and/or AsO4 2−), respectively [132]. The capacities of NN-MCM-48 (119 and 122mg/g-adsorbent for chromate and arsenate, respectively) were much larger than those of diamino-functionalized fumed silica, 79.3 and 90.7mg/g-adsorbent, respectively. This superiority would be due to the large surface area of NN-MCM-48 (BET surface area=898m2 g−1). The stoichiometry of oxyanion to nitrogen can give us information about the distribution of amino groups on the surface of mesopores as well as the adsorption mechanism (Table 8) [132]. There is no clear difference in the oxyanion/N ratio (ca. =0.4) at the adsorption saturation among the N-, NN- and NNN-MCM-48 samples, implying that two amino groups (RNH3 + or RNH2 + R′) captured one CrO4 2− or AsO4 2− by electrostatic interactions and that the organic chains are not uniformly distributed on the surface of MCM-48. It was found out that Fe, Co, Ni and Cu-coordinated amino-functionalized MCM-41 and MCM-48 work as adsorption center for arsenate and chromate based on a cation-anion interaction [133–136]. Especially, the presence of Fe(III) cation coordinated to amino ligands fixed on the surface enhanced the adsorption capacity for the oxyanions [137]. The adsorption isotherms of As(V), Cr(VI), Se(VI) and Mo(VI) oxyanions from which the adsorption capacity was determined are shown in Fig. 23 [137]. The adsorption amount reached 1.56, 0.99, 0.81 and 1.29mmolg−1 (218, 115, 116 and 206mgg−1) for arsenate, chromate, selenate and molybdate, respectively. When the initial concentration was less than or equal to 1mmoll−1, the residual oxyanion was not detected by ICP-AES after the adsorption, and the distribution coefficient K d reached higher than 200,000, indicating that the complete removal of these oxyanions was achieved. Note that the differences in the initial rise in the adsorption isotherms, and the maximum adsorption amount and K d would be attributed to the specific interactions of oxyanions with Fe3+ in addition to the simple electrostatic interaction (Table 9) [137]. The specific interactions of the oxyanions with Fe3+ contributed to the less inhibition of adsorption of the targeted oxyanion by nitrate, sulfate and chloride anions, which are present in the hydrosphere at quite high concentrations. Furthermore, the used adsorbent can be reused through the cycle of adsorption–regeneration–activation as illustrated in Fig. 24 [137], where the activation by complexation of Fe(III) cations with the amino ligands is followed by the adsorption of arsenate and simultaneous desorption of Fe(III) and arsenate by acid treatment. Recently, Wang et al. reported the preparation of well-ordered aminopropyl-functionalized SBA-15 using 6-amino-4-azahexyltrimethoxysilane via a post synthesis grafting method and its utilization as an adsorbent for Cr(VI) in aqueous solution [138]. 4.2 CO2 Amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas are ideal candidates for capturing CO2 from combustion flue gas, due to the reversible formation of ammonium carbamates and/or carbonates during CO2 adsorption, as well as due to uniform, large pores, and high surface area. Extensive researches on the adsorption of CO2 on amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas have been conducted. In 2003, Chuang et al. first reported the CO2 adsorption/desorption on SBA-15 grafted with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane. By FT-IR spectroscopy coupled with temperature-programmed desorption, CO2 was found to adsorb on the amine sites in the form of carbonate and bicarbonate (Fig. 25) [139] They also investigated the detailed mechanism of CO2 adsorption/desorption on amino-functionalized SBA-15 with in situ IR and mass spectrometries [140,141]. Yogo and his co-workers reported the reversible adsorption of CO2 on amino-functionalized SBA-15 from flue gas containing water vapor; the adsorbent was completely regenerated by heating up to 423K in He flow [142]. They also investigated the influence of amine structure on the adsorption capacity [143]. Furthermore, they developed the amino-functionalized SBA-15 membranes for CO2 separation [144]. Song et al. prepared the so-called “molecular baskets” consisting of polyethylenimine (PEI)-modified mesoporous SBA-15 molecular sieves and studied their CO2 adsorption properties [145,146]. Jones et al. reported the synthesis of the covalently tethered hyperbranched amino-functionalized SBA-15 (HAS) material capable of binding CO2 reversibly from simulated flue gas [147]. Sayari et al. extensively investigated the effects of pore expansion and amine functionalization of MCM-41 on the CO2 adsorption over a wide range of conditions [148,149]. Zhu et al. reported CO2 capture by the as-synthesized SBA-15 modified with amino groups; the as-synthesized SBA-15 was modified with tetraethylenepentamine (TEPA), as shown in Fig. 26 [150,151]. This strategy not only conserved the energy and time required for removing the template but also opened the way to utilizing the micelle for dispersing guest species. They claimed that the TEPA species dispersed within the channels of as-synthesized SBA-15 are highly accessible to CO2 molecules, and moreover that the hydroxyl group of the P123 surfactant, poly(ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide)-poly(ethylene oxide) is able to modify the interactions between CO2 and the amine, enhancing the adsorptive capacity for CO2. Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica prepared via anionic surfactant-templated route exhibited a high CO2 adsorptive performance [152,153]. In 2010, Hao et al. utilized N-lauroylsarcosine sodium (Sar-Na) as anionic SDA and 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane as CSDA for synthesizing mesostructured silica [153]. The template was efficiently removed by extraction either using a basic solution of monoethanolamine H2NCH2CH2OH (MEA) in ethanol or an acetonitrile solution acidified with HCl. Both products treated with the MEA-ethanol and acetonitrile/HCl solutions were amino-functionalized mesoporous silica nanospheres with centrosymmetric radial mesopores (Fig. 27). The product obtained treated with the MEA-ethanol solution exhibited a higher CO2 adsorption property than that with acetonitrile/HCl solution because of free amino groups available for specific interactions with CO2 as shown in Fig. 28 . Hao et al. also investigated the synthesis and CO2 adsorption properties of amino-functionalized mesoporous SBA-15; amino-functionalized SBA-15 materials were synthesized by direct co-condensation of TEOS with 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) in the presence of triblock copolymer (P123) and NH4F under acidic conditions [154]. They claimed that the presence of F− in the synthesis gel contributed to the formation of 2d-hexagonal mesoporous structure even when APTMS was present in the synthesis gel. Thus prepared amino-functionalized SBA-15 synthesized at the molar ratio of APTMS/(TEOS+APTMS)=0.3 (0.3-SBA-15-NH2) exhibited a high CO2 adsorption capacity and selectivity to CO2 over N2. They also investigated the effects of water vapor on the adsorption of CO2 on 0.30-SBA-15-NH2 by the TPD-MS technique because water vapor is always present and dramatically reduces the adsorption capacity of CO2 on most conventional adsorbents, such as zeolites (Fig. 29) [154]. When the feed of CO2 saturated with water vapor is used for CO2 adsorption at 25°C, the desorption peak area is larger than that after CO2 adsorption without the introduction of water vapor, indicating that the presence of water vapor increased the adsorbed amount of CO2. This promoting effect of water vapor would be explained on the basis of the mechanism of the reaction between CO2 and amino groups (i.e., the formation of carbamate under dry conditions and the partial formation of bicarbonate in the presence of moisture [155,156]). Very recently, Vinoba et al. reported the preparation of biocatalyst by the immobilization of human carbonic anhydrase (HCA) on gold nanoparticles assembled onto amine/thiol-functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 and its application to biomimetic sequestration of CO2 [157]. 5 Drug delivery system Recently, there has been increased interest in mesoporous silica materials applied as drug carriers in the field of controlled drug release, to meet the need for prolonged and better control of drug administration. Mesoporous silicas with a high surface area, large pore volume, uniform porosity, stable aqueous dispersion, excellent biocompatibility, in vivo biodegradability, and their capability to be functionalized with different organic groups, are attractive candidates for a wide range of biomedical purposes, such as controlled drug delivery, bone tissue regeneration, cell tracking and immobilization of proteins, enzymes, etc. In 2001, Vallet-Regi et al. first reported the capability of unfunctionalized MCM-41 for accepting and delivering ibuprofen (IBU) [158]. In this case, the host/guest system relies on the interaction between the silanol groups on the MCM-41 and the carboxylic acid moiety of the ibuprofen molecule. Thereafter, to improve the adsorption-release performance, several factors including pore size, particle size and morphology and chemical property of the mesopore surface have been investigated [159–164]. In addition to these factors, it is expected that the host/guest interaction can be modulated by modifying the interaction between the confined molecule and the silica matrix. Lin and his co-workers have extensively investigated into the design and synthesis of functionalized mesoporous silica materials for stimuli-responsive controlled release delivery of pharmaceutical drugs, genes, and other chemicals, and their works are summarized in excellent reviews [165,166]. Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica has been also applied to the host/guest system for the controlled drug delivery. In 2008, Rosenholm and Lindén reported the adsorption of salicylic acid (SA) on the amino-functionalized SBA-15 materials, which were prepared by a post-synthesis grafting method using 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane, (APTES-SBA-15) or by surface hyperbranching polymerization of poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI-COOH-SBA-15) [167]. The amounts of SA adsorbed on APTS-SBA-15, and PEI-COOH-SBA-15 were much higher than that on SBA-15. They also investigated the pH-dependent adsorption of SA, and found out that the adsorption isotherms determined for APTES-SBA-15 and PEI-COOH-SBA-15 have a volcano-shape, with a maximum close to pH 3 (Fig. 30) [167]. Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica prepared via anionic surfactant-templated route can be also used as carrier matrices in drug delivery applications. In 2009, Chen et al. reported the preparation of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica hollow spheres (MSHSs) with radially oriented mesochannels with the aid of ultrasonic irradiation, and its drug (flurbiprofen) loading and release performance [168]. Che et al. also reported the pH-responsive release system on the basis of coordination bonding in mesopores, which is exemplified by the “metal-N(amino group, guanidine, etc.)” bonding in mesopores in amino-functionalized AMS via “host–metal–guest” architecture (Fig. 31) [169]. Mesoporous silica nanoparticles with uniformly and separately distributed aminopropyl functional groups (I) on the pore surfaces serve as carriers [158,170,171]. Metal ions (II) are readily absorbed by host aminopropyl groups to form a “host–metal” coordination bond on the mesopore surface. Subsequently, guest molecules (III) are bonded to the metal ions in the carrier. The presence of a vacancy between these host functional groups caused by their isolated distribution and presence of large mesopores ensures that the metal ion are unsaturated (ignoring the weak metal–H2O coordination bonding hereafter) and capable of forming coordination bonds with guest molecules. Therefore, mesoporous materials make the “host–metal–guest” architecture possible, in which both the host functional groups and guest molecules are coordinated to metal ion binders. In addition, the host functional groups should be effective for charging of the metal ions, and the “host–guest” (I III) interaction should be weaker than both “host–metal” (I II) and “metal–guest” (II III) interactions. A breakup of either (or both) coordination bond, triggered by a reduction in external pH, leads to the release of guest molecules from the carrier into the surrounding environment. If the “host–metal” bond is stronger than the “metal–guest” bond (I II>II III), the guest molecules will be shed off with metal ions remaining on the carrier when passing through a low-pH region (route a). On the other hand, if the “host–metal” bond is weaker (I II<II III), it will break up when the carrier suffers a decrease in pH, accompanied by a simultaneous release of the guest/metal complex (route b). In the systems that use N as the electron donor (aminopropyl on the mesopore surface, guest compounds containing amino groups or guanidines, etc.), a breakup of the “host–metal” and “metal–guest” coordination bonds may possibly occur, because of the closeness of the bonding strength. Bein et al. developed an effective pH-dependent nanoscale delivery system based on ionic interactions between amino functionalities and sulfonate groups that are located at the pore entrance of colloidal mesoporous silica nanoparticles [172]. Szegedi et al. reported the effect of amine functionalization of spherical MCM-41 and SBA-15 on controlled drug release [173]. 6 Conclusion and outlook This review describes the recent progress of preparation of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica and its utilization as adsorbent, drug delivery system and solid-base catalyst. In the preparation method, the direct co-condensation would result in a homogeneous distribution of amino-organic moieties on the silica wall, and on the other hand, in the post-synthesis grafting method, most amino-organic moieties would concentrate near the openings of channels and/or on the external surface. The differences in the state and activity of the amino groups on the mesopores in the amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas synthesized via anionic and cationic surfactants templated routes have been clarified. Either the direct co-condensation in the presence of cationic or anionic surfactants or the post-synthesis grafting method for the functionalization of silicas should be properly adopted according to their applications. Up to date, there are numerous organic–inorganic hybrid mesoporous materials that have been prepared, functionalized and characterized. The realm of well-ordered mesoporous materials have been shifted to the development of unique and specific applications from their syntheses. As described above, recently, amino-functionalized mesoporous silicas have been applied to carbon dioxide adsorption and drug delivery system and these new fields will attract further attention. Meanwhile, the conversion of carbon dioxide to value-added chemicals has been featured in terms of diversification of resources. For example, one-pot synthesis of cyclic carbonate, which is useful as highly polar solvent, electrolyte components for lithium batteries and chemical intermediates in polymer synthesis, by using carbon dioxide and propylene oxide over amine-functionalized silica would be worthy to be exploited [174]. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous molecular sieves with size-tunable mesopores have been well developed and have attracted a great deal of attention because of their controllable structures and compositions, which make them suitable for a wide range of applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, chromatography, etc. The pore size of mesoporous silica is large enough to accommodate a variety of large molecules, and the high density of silanol groups on the pore wall is beneficial to the introduction of functional groups with a high coverage. Actually, various kinds of surface modifications have been conducted for providing new functions for the surfaces. Among various functional groups, the introduction of the amino groups onto the mesopores has enabled us to use amino-functionalized mesoporous materials as solid-base catalysts and adsorbents. Meanwhile, “anionic surfactant templated mesoporous silica (AMS)” has been synthesized via a novel templating route for preparing mesoporous silicas based on the self-assembly of anionic surfactants and inorganic precursors in the presence of aminosilane or quaternized aminosilane as a co-structure-directing agent. AMSs are synthetically interesting not only for their structural diversity, including chiral properties, but also for the chance of functionalizing the pore surface by removing the surfactant by solvent extraction, resulting in the formation of the mesoporous silica with aminopropyl groups intact. Thus obtained amino-functionalized AMS can be applied to solid-base catalysis, adsorption, drug delivery, etc. This review gives an overview on the recent development of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica. In particular, the difference in the state and catalytic activity of amino groups between the functionalized mesoporous silicas synthesized via anionic and cationic surfactants templating routes is featured. Interesting applications of amino-functionalized mesoporous silica besides solid-base catalyst are also described.
coredata.dc:title: Amino-functionalized mesoporous silica as base catalyst and adsorbent
